metadata.description: Treatment effectiveness rankings based on patient-reported outcomes

sample_quotes: Im on tirzepatide so not the exact same, but i lost about 2lbs a week for the first 4 months and this month it seems to have slowed down even with upping my dosage.
I think she lost 20 lbs in 6 months on sema, and tirz lost 100 in 8 months.
I started directly on tirz as my physician is also my moms and thought it’d be a better fit, and I lost 50 lbs the first time and 60 the second time.
I’ve been having modest success by increasing protein and doing low carb.
I did low carb for awhile and lost 20 lbs but was killing my self doing it.
PCOS causes issues with how your body processes carbs, so low carb approaches are a good choice.
Remember to be in a calorie deficit every day even if you have to track calories in an app.

I’ve tired calorie deficit let me explain... I thought maybe slow progress? So i decided screw the scale fast forward went to my OB for my appointment to be seen about pcos to see I weigh 230 while in a deficit!
I lost 12 pounds and 4% body fat a few years ago by doing a calorie deficit.

timeframes: some months might not lose much, but then it’ll all drop off suddenly
7 months for weight loss to start
sample_quotes: I’ve started mounjaro out of my own pocket because of their refusal to help and have lost 2 stone so far.
Have you tried getting a PA for Mounjaro? It’s has the same active medication (tirzepatide) as Zepbound, as opposed to the semaglutide in Wegovy.
I started taking mounjaro and has like 25lbs (which is awesome, since I have never lost that much weight before)
you really need to track, weigh and count everything that goes into your mouth, try intermittent fasting
I do intermitted fasting
Intermittent fasting helped me when I hit a weight plateau.
I'm not saying keto although in your case it could be helpful, but remember to not do it for too long.
I lost about 20 pounds on a very strict and annoying keto diet before my wedding.
I got there and decided to do keto and I’m finally losing again.
Do you count calories? It's not the funnest thing to do, but it's the simplest way to ensure you're maintaining a deficit.
Now I count some calories (not super strict) and exercise. I lose weight very slowly, but it does come off.
Calorie counting is a pain, but it's the best way to ensure you're truly in a deficit...
I didn’t like the metformin as it cause gastric issues for me.
I’ve been having modest success by increasing protein and doing low carb. I mostly just walk after big meals to help with bloating and digestion.
I needed to be on 10mg (one of the higher ones) for three months, and add metformin 2000mg for my body to do it.
I’m not exactly sure what the difference is between them
I have noticed I'm just not as hungry as I usually am.
I then looked to my doctor for recommendations and started ozempic.
I lost 10 pounds and my period regulated.
I just weighed myself and I am 298.6! Down 24.6lbs in 6 weeks!
Whenever i lose weight, i observe my period is getting regular
As soon as the ultrasound results came back, my Gyno put me on Metformin.
research something like metformin to discuss with your doctor when you can.
now that I’m taking metformin it’s normalized my period
She advised me to lose a bit of weight... go on birth control if I want regular periods
I’ve always been on and off birth control. Had a 3 year break until May this year, had it for 2 months, realised why i came off it (horrible side effects), then came off it at the beginning of July.
birth control is not the only treatment option for PCOS.
Recently, some of the GLP 1 agonist drugs like Ozempic are also being used, if insurance will cover them.
Recently, some of the GLP 1 agonist drugs like Ozempic are also being used, if insurance will cover them.
Recently, some of the GLP 1 agonist drugs like Ozempic are also being used, if insurance will cover them.

timeframes: 6 months to reach therapeutic dose, 1 year for management
sample_quotes: Trying Metformin just to see, if it changes anything (so far it doesn't).
She the put me on Metformin and I’ve been on it sense. It honestly hasn’t felt like it’s done anything.
Treatment of IR is done by adopting a 'diabetic' lifestyle... and by taking meds if needed (typically prescription metformin).
the supplement berberine also has some research supporting its use for IR, if inositol does not help.
The supplement berberine also has some research supporting its use for IR, if inositol does not help.
you might also try a supplement called *berberine.*
the supplement berberine also has some research supporting its use for IR.
the supplement berberine also has some research supporting its use for IR, if inositol does not help.
The supplement berberine also has some research supporting its use for IR, if inositol does not help.

timeframes: after 6 sessions and incredible results after 7th and 8th sessions
sample_quotes: Unfortunately, laser didn't work, though the first place I went to... slowed a bit, but as I grew older I guess it just stopped working.
most likely have a procedure like laser.
I’ve been lasering my face ever since I was 25. The hair is fine now
I eat low carb, take metformin and drink spearmint tea.
I’ve been drinking spearmint tea twice a day and it seems to be reducing the thickness of the hair and speed of regrowth.
Don’t forget to drink massive amounts of spearmint tea every day for hirsutism (tbf this has actually really helped).
I heard that electrolysis or something like that is a permanent solution of getting rid of hair on the body.
I did electrolysis too for almost a year, and it also didn't work. It just left my skin all red, and the pain was awful.
Electrolysis will get rid of the hairs entirely.
Now I’m 25 and it’s under control thanks to medications I did some years ago but especially because of laser treatment
I have also had laser on my face and tried every possible medication and supplements. Nothing works.
I have also had laser on my face and tried every possible medication and supplements. Nothing works.
now I have to use it another time because I’m shaving my face every day
I shave now 3 or even 4 times a day if I go somewhere in the evening. The shaving doesn’t even work because the hair is so thick.
I basically can’t shave any part of my body that gets any friction when I’m walking around.
i used to take spirinolactone 2 years ago but it was only 50mg total which ive been told now its nothing for hirsutism???
I tried spironolactone for like a week or two, but it made me have my period two times a month, so I stopped.
You could try spironolactone, its pretty cheap.
I was initially prescribed spironolactone for acne, but discontinued it after realizing it was causing dangerously low blood pressure.
Then, after pregnancy I got on spironalactone and tretinoin.
I'm on 100mg and I love it because it cleared my acne right up.
